questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion and fatigue for the past 4 months. Two years ago, she came to the office with dysphagia and underwent an upper endoscopy, which showed a dilated esophagus. There is no family history of serious illness. She emigrated from Argentina 5 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.1ºC (98.8ºF), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/62 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distension. Cardiac examination discloses an S3 gallop and a displaced left ventricular impulse. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiography shows right and left ventricular dilation and global hypokinesis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coxsackie B virus is known to cause infectious myocarditis and dilated cardiomyopathy. However, coxsackie B virus infection does not manifest with dysphagia or a dilated esophagus. Moreover, patients with coxsackie B virus infection usually present with preceding (1–2 weeks) flu-like symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Inadequate thiamine uptake can lead to beriberi, which manifests with dilated cardiomyopathy. However, thiamine deficiency does not manifest with dysphagia and megaesophagus. Moreover, patients with beriberi also present with symmetric peripheral neuropathy, confusion, and progressive muscle wasting. Finally, this patient has no known risk factors for thiamine deficiency (e.g., heavy drinking, malnutrition).

C) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of iron in the body causes hemochromatosis, which can manifest with dilated cardiomyopathy. However, patients with this condition do not present with dysphagia and a dilated esophagus. Moreover, hemochromatosis typically manifests with other organ-specific findings caused by iron accumulation in the affected organs, such as abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, features of diabetes mellitus, and bronze skin.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-topoisomerase I antibodies are seen in scleroderma, which can manifest with dysphagia and a dilated esophagus (due to esophageal hypomotility) and cardiomyopathy. However, fibroblast proliferation in the cardiac system of affected individuals results in restrictive rather than dilated cardiomyopathy. Moreover, patients with scleroderma typically present with thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, joint stiffness, and Raynaud phenomenon.

E) CORRECT:

Trypanosoma cruzi infection causes Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis), which, in the chronic phase, manifests with dilated cardiomyopathy, dysphagia, and megaesophagus (due to secondary achalasia). T. cruzi is endemic in Central and South America (e.g., Argentina) and, although some patients may develop symptoms of acute Chagas disease (e.g., fever, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, chagoma, generalized lymphadenopathy), most remain asymptomatic in the acute phase. About 10–30% of affected individuals develop chronic Chagas disease 10–20 years after the initial infection. Besides dilated cardiomyopathy and achalasia, patients with chronic Chagas disease might also present with megacolon.
Image Description:

Chagas disease is an infectious disease that affects more than 8 million individuals worldwide. The highest prevalence is in Central and South America. The vast majority of patients with Chagas disease in the United States are immigrants from Central and South America (> 300,000 infected individuals). In the US, vector-borne transmission of the disease is very rare; transplacental transmission or transmission via blood transfusion is more common.

F) INCORRECT:

Chronic tissue ischemia of the heart causes ischemic heart disease, which can manifest with dilated cardiomyopathy. However, ischemic heart disease is not associated with dysphagia or a dilated esophagus. Moreover, this patient has no history of symptoms of myocardial ischemia (e.g., angina pectoris).
questions.hint: This patient's findings of left ventricular dilation and global hypokinesis on echocardiography are consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy, which typically manifests with features of congestive heart failure (CHF; e.g., progressive exertional dyspnea, jugular venous distension, S3 gallop, displaced left ventricular impulse). ECG findings of left ventricular hypertrophy are common in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fever, recurrent headaches, and anorexia. One month ago, she returned from a camping trip in Chile. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). Examination shows a swelling in the left periorbital region and axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. A blood sample is obtained. Processing of the sample with which of the following methods is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staining with crystal violet dyes (e.g., Gram stain) is the standard approach for identifying and classifying bacteria in a specimen. Although this patient does present with nonspecific symptoms of infection (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy), and Gram stain would be useful for excluding a bacterial cause, her unilateral periorbital swelling in particular warrants an initial diagnostic step toward diagnosing Chagas disease, which is caused by a protozoan.

B) INCORRECT:

Mycolic acid staining (e.g. Ziehl-Neelsen stain) is used to identify acid-fast organisms such as mycobacteria. Tuberculosis (TB) can present with a myriad of symptoms, including those seen here (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy). However, her unilateral periorbital swelling warrants an initial diagnostic step toward diagnosing Chagas disease instead.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Ziehl-Neelsen stain; 1000× magnification)

The curved, rod-shaped bacteria appear bright red after staining.

C) INCORRECT:

India ink staining is used to identify the thick polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus neoformans, which most typically causes pneumonia and meningoencephalitis in immunocompromised patients. Although this patient does have symptoms indicating some type of infection (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy), disseminated lymphadenopathy and unilateral periorbital swelling after travel abroad is not consistent with C. neoformans infection in a previously healthy patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

D) CORRECT:

Chagas disease is caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted by inoculation of fecal material of the triatomine reduvid bug into skin or mucous membranes. The reduvid bug preferentially bites on the face (“kissing bug”). The Romana sign occurs when the portal of entry of T. cruzi is the conjunctiva or eyelid. The pathogen subsequently disseminates via the bloodstream. Staining this patient's peripheral blood with stains that contain aniline dyes (e.g, Giemsa stain, Wright stain) would likely reveal the presence of Trypanosoma cruzi trypomastigotes. Treatment with benznidazole or nifurtimox is necessary to prevent complications of Chagas disease such as dilated cardiomyopathy, megaesophagus, and acute megacolon.
Image Description:

Blood smear (Giemsa stain, 100x magnification)

The parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, can be seen in the center of this blood smear (green overlay). Its characteristic flagellum (yellow overlay) is clearly recognizable.

E) INCORRECT:

Glycogen staining methods, such as in periodic acid-Schiff stains, are useful in diagnosing Whipple disease. Although this patient does present with nonspecific symptoms of infection (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy), she does not have the enteropathic arthritis, neurological symptoms, or chronic diarrhea and insidious malabsorption typical for Whipple disease. Rather, her unilateral periorbital swelling is characteristic of Chagas disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph (very high magnification, Periodic acid-Schiff stain) of a duodenal biopsy

Within the cytoplasm of the macrophages, granular PAS-positive material is visible.

This appearance is suggestive of Whipple disease, which is caused by Tropheryma whippleii.

F) INCORRECT:

Silver staining is useful for identifying fungi (e.g., Coccidioides) as well as some bacteria (e.g., H. pylori, Legionella pneumophila). Legionella pneumophila infection (legionellosis) could cause the nonspecific features seen here (e.g., fever, lymphadenopathy) but it would also cause respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough) or GI symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, diarrhea), which are not reported by this patient. Unilateral periorbital swelling is characteristic of Chagas disease, which cannot be diagnosed by silver stain.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Coccidioides immitis in lung tissue (methenamine silver stain; high magnification)

Spherule (red circles) and endospore (green overlays) forms of Coccidioides immitis, a causative agent of coccidioidomycosis, can be seen.

G) INCORRECT:

A stain that reacts with iron (Prussian blue stain) is used to identify iron deposits (e.g., hemosiderin in hemochromatosis, ferruginous bodies in asbestosis, marrow sideroblasts in sideroblastic anemia). This patient has features of an infection (e.g., high fever, lymphadenopathy). Stains containing iron (e.g, colloidal iron stain, iron-hematoxylin trichome stain) can be used to stain pathogens that are rich in mucopolysaccharides but stains that react with iron are rarely used in clinical microbiology.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue sample (Prussian blue stain)

Prussian blue stains the iron deposits dark blue (green arrows) and the nuclei bright red. A portal triad (P; green overlay) is visible in the lower left corner.
questions.hint: This patient traveled to an area where Chagas disease is endemic (Central and South America) and now presents with features of infection (e.g., high fever, lymphadenopathy) and unilateral periorbital swelling (Romana sign), which are very characteristic of acute Chagas disease.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of headache, loss of appetite, diarrhea, and swelling of her jaw. She recently returned from a 5-week hiking and camping trip in Mexico. She appears unwell. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 119/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a painful swelling and erythema of the skin in the left mandibular area. A photomicrograph of her peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is a nitroimidazole antibiotic used for the treatment of infections caused by a number of protozoa (e.g., Giardia, E. histolytica, Trichomonas) and anaerobic bacteria. The photomicrograph of this patient's peripheral blood smear suggests a disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, which is not covered by the spectrum of action of metronidazole.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a laboratory culture (Giemsa stain; 100x magnification)

Eleven pear-shaped trophozoites, each with four pairs of flagella (black arrows), two nuclei of equal size (green overlay), and one or two median bodies (hatched green overlay), are visible.

These features are characteristic of Giardia lamblia trophozoites.

B) INCORRECT:

Artesunate is an antimalarial drug most commonly used for the treatment of severe falciparum malaria, which is typically caused by Plasmodium falciparum. Malaria can manifest with fever, headache, loss of appetite, and diarrhea. However, neither painful swelling and erythema of the skin nor peripheral blood smear showing trypomastigotes would be expected. Moreover, severe falciparum malaria typically manifests with clinical features such as impaired consciousness, bleeding, renal failure, hepatic failure, pulmonary edema, and severe hemolytic anemia, which are more severe than those seen in this patient. The diagnosis of malaria is made by detecting the Plasmodium parasites within RBCs. Finally, most cases of malaria occur in tropical Africa rather than Mexico.
Image Description:

Compared to other forms of malaria, trophozoites of falciparum malaria are characterized by smaller and finer ring-shaped inclusions (green overlay). Plasmodium falciparum invades many erythrocytes, and one erythrocyte is typically invaded by more than one plasmodium, which is not the case in other forms of malaria.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitazoxanide is an antiparasitic drug used to treat infectious diarrhea due to Cryptosporidium parvum or Giardia lamblia. Although cryptosporidiosis and giardiasis may manifest with diarrhea and fever, they do not typically manifest with painful swelling and erythema of the skin. Moreover, the photomicrograph of this patient's peripheral blood smear suggests a disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, which is not covered by the spectrum of action of nitazoxanide.
Image Description:

Fecal sample of a patient with cryptosporidiosis

Several round oocysts (red) that contain a large number of sporozoites. Oocysts are highly resistant to environmental factors and disinfectants (also to chlorine, e.g., in drinking water). They are the infective form of the parasite Cryptosporidium parvum.

D) INCORRECT:

Melarsoprol is an antiparasitic drug that can cross the blood-brain barrier and is used for the treatment of stage II of African trypanosomiasis, which is caused by Trypanosoma brucei. Vector transmission occurs via tsetse fly bite, and may result in fever, painful swelling and erythema of the skin, headache, and trypomastigotes on a peripheral blood smear. However, this patient does not have other typical findings of African trypanosomiasis (e.g., lymphadenopathy, anemia, behavioral changes, daytime somnolence, ataxia, Kerandel sign, coma). Moreover, this condition is endemic to Sub-Saharan Africa, not Central America.
Image Description:

Blood smear (Giemsa stain)

Extracellular trypanosomes (Trypanosoma brucei) are visible with a typical streamlined and tapered shape and a flagellum that arises from the basal body.

E) CORRECT:

Fever, headache, loss of appetite, diarrhea, painful swelling and erythema of the skin in the left mandibular area (chagoma), and history of recent travel to Mexico are suggestive of the acute phase of Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis), which is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. Vector transmission for this protozoan parasite occurs via the bite of an insect of the Reduviidae family (“kissing bug”) and occurs almost exclusively in Central and South America. Direct visualization of T. cruzi trypomastigotes in peripheral blood smear, as seen in this patient, confirms the diagnosis of acute infection. The first-line of treatment for Chagas disease is benznidazole, an antitrypanosomal drug. Treatment of Chagas disease is most effective when initiated in the acute phase.
Image Description:

Chagas disease is an infectious disease that affects more than 8 million individuals worldwide. The highest prevalence is in Central and South America. The vast majority of patients with Chagas disease in the United States are immigrants from Central and South America (> 300,000 infected individuals). In the US, vector-borne transmission of the disease is very rare; transplacental transmission or transmission via blood transfusion is more common.

F) INCORRECT:

Stibogluconate is a drug used for the treatment of complicated cutaneous leishmaniasis, which is caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania donovani. Cutaneous leishmaniasis is endemic in Mexico, but cutaneous leishmaniasis manifestations typically do not include fever, headache, loss of appetite, and diarrhea. The typical skin findings of this condition are macules/papules around the sandfly bite that quickly increase in size and develop central ulceration, which are not seen in this patient. Finally, the diagnosis is made by detecting the pathogen in a skin biopsy, rather than by peripheral blood smear.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin biopsy (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Ovoid, dark purple inclusions (examples indicated by white arrows) are visible within macrophages. The nuclei (green overlay) appear normal.

This appearance is typical of amastigotes, the intracellular, nonmotile form of the parasite Leishmania major.
questions.hint: This photomicrograph shows Trypanosoma cruzi, with its characteristic flagellum in the center.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman from El Salvador who moved to the United States 8 years ago is hospitalized for abrupt onset of palpitations and dizziness while watching television. The patient reports progressive dyspnea on moderate exertion for the past 2 months but no other symptoms or recent illnesses. She was prescribed a proton pump inhibitor 6 months ago, when she was diagnosed with esophageal dilatation and dysmotility. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs, and she rarely drinks alcohol.
On physical examination, she is comfortable and has normal vital signs. Her head, neck, and lungs are normal.
Her heart is enlarged, with a forceful left ventricular lift and occasional premature beats. A third heart sound is audible, but no fourth heart sound or murmur is audible. An electrocardiogram reveals a right bundle-branch block. An echocardiogram identifies a dilated left ventricle with an ejection fraction of 45%.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fat-pad biopsy is used to diagnose amyloidosis. This patient’s presentation is not typical of amyloidosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Without echocardiographic evidence suggesting myocarditis, myocardial biopsies are not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

In the absence of symptoms, signs, or electrocardiographic findings suggestive of myocardial ischemia, myocardial perfusion imaging is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme can be useful as a disease marker in patients being treated for sarcoidosis. Although sarcoidosis can cause a right bundle-branch block, it is not typically associated with a dilated esophagus.

E) CORRECT:

This patient from Central America should undergo serologic testing for Chagas disease, specifically to detect immunoglobulin G antibodies to Trypanosoma cruzi.

Chagas disease becomes clinically evident 10 to 30 years after acute infection by affecting specific organs, particularly the heart, esophagus, or colon. Patients may have cardiac manifestations, digestive manifestations (i.e., abnormal enlargement and dysfunction of the esophagus or colon), or a mixture of the two. Cardiac manifestations of Chagas disease include sinus-node dysfunction, conduction-system abnormalities (i.e., bundle-branch and high-degree heart block), ventricular tachycardia, segmental left ventricular wall-motion abnormalities, apical aneurysm, embolic phenomena due to ventricular thrombus formation, and a progressively dilated cardiomyopathy with congestive heart failure.

Key learning point: A woman in her early forties from Central America who has esophageal dysfunction, conduction system abnormalities, and dilated cardiomyopathy should undergo testing for Chagas disease, with serologic testing for Trypanosoma cruzi.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man with no known medical history presents to the emergency department after experiencing syncope while jogging. He lost consciousness for only a few seconds; the episode was not accompanied by incontinence or seizure-like activity. He reports no nausea or chest pain but has been experiencing increasing dyspnea on exertion for several weeks. He takes no medications and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. He emigrated from Guatemala 5 years ago but has no recent travel history.
His physical examination is notable for a heart rate of 55 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 110/68 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while he is breathing ambient air. He has clear lung fields bilaterally, an S1 heart sound that varies in intensity, no murmurs, and an unremarkable neurologic examination.
A basic metabolic panel, cardiac enzyme evaluation, thyroid studies, and a chest radiograph are unremarkable. An echocardiogram reveals normal left ventricular structure and function.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
What is the mostly likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause valvular disease, pericardial disease, or myocarditis, but CHB is rare in adults with systemic lupus.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiogram reveals complete heart block (CHB). Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi and endemic in Latin America, can lead to chronic myocardial inflammation. Although reduced left ventricular systolic function and cardiomyopathy are common cardiac manifestations, conduction-system abnormalities are often the earliest indicators of Chagas cardiomyopathy, and CHB can occur without structural heart abnormalities. CHB is sometimes associated with a first heart sound of varying intensity, which was noted in this patient.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of complete heart block in a young patient from Latin America with no other cardiac history, a normal echocardiogram, and a normal basic laboratory workup is Chagas cardiomyopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral myocarditis can cause a dilated cardiomyopathy and symptoms of heart failure, but it is rarely associated with CHB.

D) INCORRECT:

Myocardial bridging occurs when an epicardial coronary artery tunnels through and is compressed by the myocardium. It very rarely causes symptoms and does not cause CHB.

E) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis typically causes CHB and other arrhythmias only in patients who have other features of sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman from Venezuela presents with a 2-week history of fever, malaise, and fatigue. She arrived in the US 5 weeks ago, having traveled overland through Central America, and lives in a crowded apartment. Physical examination shows left conjunctival injection with unilateral painless periocular edema, enlarged preauricular lymph nodes, and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Vital signs are BP, 118/76; P, 92; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). She is alert and fully oriented. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?

choices.text: Serum antibody testing for Trypanosoma cruzi
Thick and thin peripheral blood smears
CT scan of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is indicated if meningoencephalitis is suspected. This patient's neurological status is not altered, and the constellation of findings points toward typical acute systemic disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiogram is indicated for suspected Chagas cardiomyopathy, but Chagas cardiomyopathy typically develops in the chronic phase after 10–20 years of infection. While cardiac complications can occur rarely in acute disease, the initial focus is on confirming the parasitic infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum antibody testing for Trypanosoma cruzi is used in the indeterminate and chronic phases of Chagas disease when parasitemia is low or absent. In the acute phase, direct parasite visualization is preferred because it provides immediate confirmation and antibody levels may not yet be detectable.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The clinical presentation of fever, malaise, unilateral painless periocular edema with conjunctival injection, preauricular lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly in a patient from an endemic area suggests acute Chagas disease. In the acute phase, direct visualization of Trypanosoma cruzi trypomastigotes in thick and thin peripheral blood smears using Giemsa stain is the best initial diagnostic test. This patient has a 2-week history of symptoms, well within the acute phase (8–12 weeks).

E) INCORRECT:

CT imaging is appropriate for suspected orbital cellulitis or other structural causes of periocular swelling. This patient's painless edema, systemic symptoms, and epidemiological factors make systemic parasitic infection more likely.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 10-day history of fever, malaise, and facial swelling. She reports staying at her cousin's house in a rural area during a recent trip to Guatemala. Physical examination shows unilateral periocular edema, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral blood smears show motile trypomastigotes. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Benznidazole is the first-line antitrypanosomal therapy for acute Chagas disease. Treatment is most effective when initiated early in the acute phase, when parasites are present in the blood. This patient has confirmed acute Chagas disease with positive blood smears showing trypomastigotes, making immediate antitrypanosomal therapy the priority.

B) INCORRECT:

Serological testing for IgG antibodies is used to diagnose Chagas disease in the indeterminate and chronic phases. This patient already has confirmed acute disease with positive blood smears.

C) INCORRECT:

Barium swallow study evaluates for megaesophagus and achalasia, which are gastrointestinal manifestations of chronic Chagas disease, not acute infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to evaluate for Chagas cardiomyopathy, but this typically occurs in the chronic phase, years after initial infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Nifurtimox is second-line antitrypanosomal therapy for Chagas disease. Benznidazole is preferred as first-line treatment because of its better safety profile.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the clinic because of worsening abdominal distension and constipation for the past year. He reports having bowel movements only once every 10–14 days despite using over-the-counter laxatives. Over the past month, he has developed intermittent crampy abdominal pain with bloating. He has also had an “unbearable” burning sensation in his feet for the past 3 months, for which he has been taking oxycodone. He emigrated from Bolivia to the United States 10 years ago. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include intermediate-acting insulin twice daily and insulin lispro before meals. Family history is unremarkable. He appears tired but is not in acute distress. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a protuberant, tympanic abdomen with decreased bowel sounds and mild diffuse tenderness. Rectal examination shows an empty rectal vault. An abdominal x-ray shows marked dilation of the colon, especially the sigmoid and rectum, without evidence of obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s gastrointestinal findings?

choices.text: Destruction of enteric nervous system by Trypanosoma cruzi infection
Chronic opioid use leading to decreased colonic motility
Chronic ischemic injury to the inferior mesenteric artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

RET proto-oncogene mutations cause Hirschsprung disease, a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of enteric ganglia in the distal colon, leading to chronic constipation and colonic dilation. However, Hirschsprung disease manifests almost exclusively in infancy or childhood. A different diagnosis is more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, is endemic to Central and South America (e.g., Bolivia). The disease can enter a chronic phase years or decades after an acute infection. In the chronic phase, the parasite destroys nerve ganglia (the myenteric plexus) within the muscular walls of hollow organs. In the colon, it causes progressive destruction of the submucosal and myenteric plexus, resulting in loss of peristalsis, chronic constipation, and, eventually, megacolon. Diagnosis is confirmed with serology. Treatment involves a high-fiber diet with adequate fluid intake, laxatives, and/or rectal enemas for constipation.

Other classic complications of chronic Chagas disease include megaesophagus and Chagas cardiomyopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of the myenteric plexus can occur in rare conditions, such as autoimmune gastrointestinal dysmotility, and is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes or systemic autoimmune diseases. This patient has no history of malignancy or autoimmune disease, making this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Opioids can cause constipation by decreasing gastrointestinal motility via μ-opioid receptor activation in the colon. However, opioid-induced constipation does not cause megacolon or empty rectal vault and typically occurs immediately after starting therapy. This patient’s severe, longstanding constipation and epidemiological risk factors point to a different etiology.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic mesenteric ischemia manifests with postprandial abdominal pain, sitophobia, and unintended weight loss, none of which this patient has. Additionally, this condition causes colonic strictures and/or segmental narrowing, not diffuse colonic dilation.
questions.hint: The combination of abdominal pain and distension, constipation, and dilation of the colon in the absence of a mechanical obstruction raises suspicion for megacolon.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive difficulty swallowing solids and liquids over the past 4 months. She has lost 4 kg (9 lb) during this period. There is no history of serious illness. She emigrated to the US from Panama 7 years ago. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a systolic murmur and an S3 gallop. A barium radiograph of the chest is shown. Endoscopic biopsy of the distal esophagus is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Atrophy of esophageal smooth muscle cells
Infiltration of eosinophils in the epithelium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Loss of esophageal smooth muscle is commonly seen in patients with diffuse or limited systemic sclerosis. Loss of muscle results in esophageal hypomotility and lower esophageal sphincter incompetence, which can manifest as progressive dysphagia and dilation of the esophagus on a barium esophagram. However, the gastro-esophageal junction would be open rather than narrowed. Moreover, this patient does not have features of systemic sclerosis (e.g., thickened skin, sclerodactyly, mask-like facies).

B) INCORRECT:

Intranuclear basophilic inclusions are aggregates of viral replication-associated proteins commonly seen in CMV infections. CMV esophagitis can cause dysphagia, which is seen in this patient. However, CMV would not cause achalasia and only rarely leads to cardiomyopathy. Furthermore, most patients presenting with CMV esophagitis are immunocompromised, with CD4 counts ≤ 50. This patient's relatively unremarkable medical history suggests that she is immunocompetent.

C) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of eosinophils in the epithelium is the hallmark of eosinophilic esophagitis, which is often seen in patients with atopic tendency. It is characterized by mucosal fragility and inflammation, which can manifest with dysphagia. A barium esophagram or endoscopy may reveal formed rings or small strictures arranged in consequent ridges/furrows ("corrugated esophagus"), but not esophageal dilation. Furthermore, eosinophilic esophagitis is not associated with dilated cardiomyopathy.

D) CORRECT:

Chagas disease is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi infection, a parasite endemic to regions of Central and South America. In addition to dilated cardiomyopathy, T. cruzi infection can lead to denervation and destruction of myenteric plexus neurons anywhere along the gastrointestinal tract. This results in an inability to relax the lower esophageal sphincter (achalasia), which manifests as progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and a bird-beak sign on barium swallow.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of metaplastic columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus is a hallmark of Barrett esophagus. This condition is characterized by the transformation of stratified squamous epithelium to metaplastic columnar epithelium after the esophageal mucosa is chronically exposed to stomach acid in GERD. This patient has no history of retrosternal pain (heartburn), which would potentially indicate GERD. Furthermore, Barrett esophagus is not typically associated with cardiomyopathy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an esophageal tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain; intermediate magnification)

The upper right edge of the image shows physiological multilayered squamous epithelium of the esophageal mucosa (white overlay), which changes into metaplastic prismatic epithelium with goblet cells (Barrett metaplasia; yellow overlay) toward the center of the image. Barrett metaplasia can eventually develop into epithelial dysplasia and, further, to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus (blue overlay). The carcinoma is characterized by loss of tissue architecture (atypical to absent gland formation) and invasive growth.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: Clinical features of dilated cardiomyopathy (e.g., systolic murmur due to mitral regurgitation, S3 gallop) in a patient from Central America is suggestive of Chagas disease.
